description: This course aims to cultivate preservice teachers’ pedagogical content knowledge in IB education with an emphasis on the MYP. Preservice teachers will learn that MYP has a curriculum framework and explore IB standards. They will learn how to construct interdisciplinary units and inquiry-based learning through proposing quality statement of inquiry, engaging ATT and ATL in units, and planning appropriate formative assessments. Strategies to supervise MYP students to work on service as action and personal projects are also discussed in class. Examining IB MYP publications and collaborating with peer are required. Workshop leaders are also invited to prepare preservice teachers to become candidates of IB practitioners.
goals: Know how topics in subject content can be learned and taught in alignment to IB principles
Show the competence to deconstruct the intended learning goals and develop corresponding materials
Design learning activities and teaching strategies that are developmental appropriate to learners aged 12 to 16 to promote inquiry and support the achievement of learning objectives.
Be able to communicate and collaborate with peers within different teacher communities.
Develop the competence to select, design and evaluate appropriate teaching and learning materials that are authentic and integrate global contexts/ international-mindedness.
syllabus:
本課程為全英語授課。

**Instructor**

Dr. Eric Jabal, Visiting Assistant Professor

[ericjabal@ntnu.edu.tw](mailto:ericjabal@ntnu.edu.tw)  

**Course objectives**

This course aims to cultivate preservice teachers’ (PTs) pedagogical knowledge in IB education with an emphasis on the IB Middle Years Programme (MYP) curriculum framework and IB standards for schools. As learning is “a social event \[that\] requires interaction with multiple individuals, including peers” (Dawley, 2007), PTs will explore the conditions for cultivating student inquiry through case study, interactive, and direct instruction. In the process of using concept-based teaching and learning models of instruction, PTs will:

*   construct meaningful inquiries using key and related concepts that combine with global contexts (facts, skills, conceptual understanding) to form a statement of inquiry and address subject group objectives;
*   plan appropriate formative and summative assessments that take up factual, conceptual, and debatable inquiry questions; and
*   apply engaging approaches to learning (ATL) in the classroom as part of role playing and simulations.

Strategies to advise and supervise MYP students to participate in service and action and complete a personal (or community) project are also discussed in class. Over the course of the 18 topics of study delivered in a combination of online dialogues/blogs and face-to-face class interactions at NTNU, PTs are required to examine IB publications, collaborate with peers, consider multiple perspectives, and demonstrate their understanding of the MYP principles and practice through small group presentations and individual written reflection papers.

 **COURSE ASSIGNMENT RUBRICS (1abc, 2abc)**
-------------------------------------------

_Blog and vlog reflections – level of critical thinking, engagement displayed, and use of media (vlog) in the post_

**EXCELLENT**

**(4 points)**

**SATISFACTORY**

**(3 points)**

**UNDER-DEVELOPED**

**(2 points)**

**LIMITED**

**(1 point)**

**NO CREDIT**

**(0 points)**

**Critical thinking**

*   The blog post is focused and coherently integrates examples with explanations or analysis.
*   The post demonstrates awareness of its own limitations or implications, and it considers multiple perspectives when appropriate.

*   The blog post is reasonably focused, and explanations or analysis are mostly based on examples or other evidence.
*   Fewer connections are made between ideas, and though new insights are offered, they are not fully developed.

*   The blog post is mostly description or summary, without consideration of alternative perspectives, and few connections are made between ideas.

*   The blog post is unfocused, or simply rehashes previous comments.

The blog post is missing or consists of one or two disconnected sentences.

**Engagement**

*   The entry reflects in-depth engagement with the topic in a substantive way. Reply pushes understanding of topic further.

*   The post reflects moderate engagement with the topic. Reply critiques / comments in a cursory way.

*   The post reflects passing engagement with the topic. Reply engages in a superficial way.

*   The post displays no evidence of student engagement with the topic.

**Use of media**

*   Vlog displays a mastery of the media: visual elements are clear and support reflective quality of vlog post.

*   Vlog displays a competent use of media: visual elements are mostly clear and support a generally reflective vlog post.

*   Vlog displays inconsistent use of the media: visual elements are vague and vlog post displays a lack of reflective qualities.
